Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides travel support of participants to the conference titled "Talking Across Fields" will take place at Stanford University, on January 31-February 2, 2020. It is expected to gather about 17 talks given by some of the world leaders in combinatorics, probability, and statistics, and more than fifty other participants.

The purpose of this meeting is to explore the fundamental connections between probability, combinatorics, algebra, and their applications in statistics and scientific computing. In particular, the meeting will explore recent advances in rates of convergence of Markov chains, exchangeability, random graphs, and sampling, and the foundational role they play in our understanding of randomness, symmetry, and computation.
The conference webpage can be found at the URL https://statistics.stanford.edu/conferences/talking-across-fields

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of the conference "Talking across fields" was to asemble some of the leading experts in the fields of Probability, Combinatorics, Algebra, Statistics, and Machine Learning, and have them give talks on their current research. We were fortunate to have 15 of the world's experts in these topics as speaking participants, the names of whom are given below:

  • David Aldous, University of California Berkeley
  • Georgia Benkart, University of Wisconsin-Madison
  • Alexei Borodin, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
  • Steve Evans, University of California Berkeley
  • Susan Holmes, Stanford University
  • Donald Knuth, Stanford University
  • Laurent Miclo, University of Toulouse
  • Evita Nestoridi, Princeton University
  • Jim Pitman, University of California Berkeley
  • Charles Radin, University of Texas at Austin
  • Arun Ram, University of Melbourne
  • Brian Skyrms, University of California Irvine
  • Richard Stanley, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
  • Steve Stigler, University of Chicago
  • Sandy Zabell, Northwestern University

 The talks were all open to the public, and were well attended by junior researchers (PhD students, post docs, and junior faculty). The talks provided young researchers an opportunity to learn the state of the art in problems of interest, and possible strategies in solving them. This should provide a blueprint  for future research. A link to the confererence website is given below:

https://statistics.stanford.edu/conferences/talking-across-fields
